sections.title: What this section covers
sections.content:
**Countable** nouns (can be singular or plural: a book, two books).

**Uncountable** nouns (no plural with -s: water, information, advice).

**Nouns that are always plural** (e.g. scissors, trousers).

• **Check** – test your understanding.
• **Practice** – correct common mistakes.

sections.title: Countable vs uncountable
sections.content:
**Countable** – you can count them. Use **a/an** and plural **-s**:

• a book, two books; an apple, three apples
• **many** books, **few** books, **a few** books
• **How many** books?

**Uncountable** – treated as one mass. No **a/an**, no plural -s:

• water, information, advice, rice, money, furniture
• **much** water, **little** water, **a little** water
• **How much** water?

Wrong: *a water*, *two advices*. Right: **some water**, **some advice** (or **a bottle of water**, **a piece of advice**).

sections.title: Common mistakes (uncountable in English)
sections.content:
These are **uncountable** in English – no plural -s, no *a/an*:

• **advice** (not *advices*): Give me some advice. A piece of advice.
• **information** (not *informations*): I need more information.
• **news** (not *a news*): The news is good. (singular verb)
• **furniture** (not *furnitures*): We need new furniture.
• **homework** (not *homeworks*): I have a lot of homework.
• **research** (not *researches*): She does research.
• **luggage / baggage** (not *luggages*): How much luggage?
• **weather** (not *a weather*): The weather is nice.
• **progress** (not *progresses*): We're making progress.
• **hair** (uncountable when = all hair on head): She has long hair. (But: three hairs on the jacket = countable.)

sections.title: Nouns that are always plural
sections.content:
Some nouns have **only a plural form**. They take a **plural verb**:

• **scissors** – The scissors are on the table. (Not: *a scissor*)
• **trousers / pants** – These trousers are too long.
• **jeans, shorts, pyjamas** – My jeans are blue.
• **glasses** (spectacles) – Where are my glasses?
• **congratulations** – Congratulations are in order.
• **thanks** – Thanks were given.

To talk about **one item**, we say **a pair of**: a pair of scissors, a pair of trousers, a pair of glasses.

Wrong: *a scissors*, *this trousers*. Right: **a pair of scissors**, **these trousers** (plural verb).

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• **Countable:** a book, two books; many/few; How many?
• **Uncountable:** (no a/an, no -s) advice, information, news, furniture, homework; much/little; How much?
• **Always plural:** scissors, trousers, jeans, glasses – plural verb; one item = a pair of.
• Don't say: advices, informations, a news, a scissors.

questions.question: Which is correct?
questions.explanation: Advice is uncountable in English. Use 'some advice' or 'a piece of advice'.

questions.question: Which is correct?

options.a: The scissors is on the table.
options.b: The scissors are on the table.
options.c: A scissors is on the table.
options.d: The scissor is on the table.

questions.explanation: Scissors is always plural and takes a plural verb (are).

questions.question: Which is correct?

options.b: I have a lot of homework.

questions.explanation: Homework is uncountable. Use 'a lot of homework' or 'some homework'.

questions.question: Which is correct?
questions.explanation: Trousers is always plural; use 'these' and a plural verb (are).

questions.question: Which is correct?
questions.explanation: News is uncountable and takes a singular verb (is).

questions.question: Wrong: 'Can you give me an advice?' Correct the sentence.
answers: Can you give me some advice?
Can you give me a piece of advice?
Can you give me some advice
Can you give me a piece of advice
questions.explanation: Advice is uncountable; use 'some advice' or 'a piece of advice'.

questions.question: Wrong: 'I need more informations.' Correct the sentence.
Wrong: 'Where is my glasses?' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Glasses (spectacles) is always plural; use plural verb (are).

questions.question: Wrong: 'She has many homeworks.' Correct the sentence.
answers: She has a lot of homework.
She has a lot of homework
questions.explanation: Homework is uncountable; use 'a lot of' or 'lots of'.

questions.question: Wrong: 'The scissors is in the drawer.' Correct the sentence.
answers: The scissors are in the drawer.
The scissors are in the drawer
questions.explanation: Scissors is always plural; use plural verb (are).

questions.question: Wrong: 'We have made a good progress.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Progress is uncountable; no 'a' before it.

questions.question: Wrong: 'These jeans is too tight.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Jeans is always plural; use plural verb (are).

questions.question: Wrong: 'I have too many luggages.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Luggage is uncountable; use 'much' and no -s.

questions.question: Wrong: 'The furniture are old.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Furniture is uncountable and takes a singular verb (is).

questions.question: Wrong: 'He did a research.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Research is uncountable; no 'a'. Use 'research' or 'some research'.
